Astronomy, the scientific study of celestial objects and phenomena, has made tremendous progress in understanding the universe. The use of the parallax method has enabled astronomers to accurately determine the distances to nearby stars. By analyzing the apparent shift of a nearby star against the background of more distant stars when viewed from opposite sides of the Earth's orbit, scientists can calculate the star's distance with high precision. Additionally, the study of orbital periods has provided valuable insights into the properties of celestial bodies, such as the rotation rates and orbital characteristics of planets and asteroids. The discovery of stellar nurseries, regions of space where new stars are born, has also shed light on the life cycle of stars. Modern telescopes, with their advanced technologies, have enabled astronomers to observe the universe in unprecedented detail, from the faint light of distant galaxies to the explosive events of supernovae.
